Hi Darin, 
You might find Breaking into Local Government: A Guidebook for Career Changers to be useful in learning how you can break in at different levels in local government icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/305351. 
Additionally you can always contact local government officials in your area and network with them and ask if a transition is possible and what skills you should work on developing while you are still in school. There are also over 49,000 users with profiles on the Knowledge Network so you can search my job description and location to find people to network on here as well. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/people/whos_who
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

answers.author: Josh Jones
answers.text:
Hi Darin, I'm sorry that you haven't gotten more responses by now. While I can't say for certain, I would highly encourage you to try and make the switch that you desire. There's no doubt that recruitments are competitive, but strange things happen in recruitments that allow people of varying backgrounds and skill sets to shine through. I'm quite certain that you'll land something as you apply to a variety of city organizations. And, I completely understand that no one would want to start at the bottom as a budget anaylst after 17 years of managing a budget.

author: Darin Clements
text:
I'm currently pursuing my MPA at the ripe old age of 40 and am looking to transition from my current career into municipal finance. I am currently in a senior position with a state university managing my office/department, a $1,000,000 budget and administering over $15,000,000 in grants. 
 My question is simple; how can I transition into the municipal side of public employment without starting at the bottom? If my only choice is starting at the bottom, I'll stay in higher ed, where my 17 years actually mean something. Thanks in advance.
title: Mid-Career Move
